org.cs3.pdt.runtime
Interface PersistableSubscription

All Superinterfaces:
Subscription
All Known Implementing Classes:
DefaultSubscription
public interface PersistableSubscription
extends Subscription

A Subscription that can be persisted. PersistableSubscriptions can store/restore their complete state to/from a key->value map. It is the responsibility of the implementing class to supply adaequat implementations to saveState() and restoreState(Map). implementing classes MUST be default-constructable.

Author:
lukas

Methods inherited from interface org.cs3.pdt.runtime.Subscription
configure, deconfigure, getDescritpion, getId, getName, getPifKey
 

Method Detail

getHostId

public java.lang.String getHostId()
retrieve the bundle id of the hosting plugin. when the subscription is restored, the host bundle needs to be known, so the correct classloader is used.

Returns:
the bundle id of the plugin hosting the subscription.

restoreState

public void restoreState(java.util.Map params)
Restore from saved state. This is called by the registry. Implementations should use this method to completely initialize their state according to the given parameter values. The framework assumes that the subscription is completely initialized after this call.

Parameters:
params - a map of parameternames and respective values. Key and value type is String. This map contains the same data as the on that was previously returned by saveState.

saveState

public java.util.Map saveState()
save state. This method is called by the framework before shutdown. Implementations should return a (modifyable!) map of parameter names and respective values. Key and value type MUST be String. The map should contain enough information to completely restore the state by calling restoreState(Map) on an uninitialized Instance.

Returns:
the saved state.

isPersistent

public boolean isPersistent()
Check wether this subscription should be persisted on shutdown.

Returns:
if true, the framework will save the state on shutdown using saveState() and restore it at next startup using restoreState().
